nodes.text: The Naive Bayes classifier is an effective and reliable method for identifying and filtering spam emails

We applied a multinomial-style Naive Bayes text classification pipeline including text cleaning, tokenization, Bag of Words feature extraction, Laplace smoothing, and prediction by comparing posterior probabilities
The study used a combined dataset of 83,446 emails from the 2007 TREC Public Spam Corpus and the Enron-Spam Dataset labeled spam or ham
Model selection used 5-fold cross validation on the training data and final evaluation used an 80/20 random train/test split
Naive Bayes assumes conditional independence of words, enabling efficient probability calculations by multiplying per-word likelihoods given class labels
Data preprocessing consisted of removing noninformative characters and stop words, lowercasing, tokenizing into words, and building Bag of Words frequency vectors
Likelihoods for words were estimated by term frequencies per class with Laplace smoothing to avoid zero probabilities
The merged dataset contained 83,446 emails: 43,910 spam (52.62 percent) and 39,538 ham (47.38 percent)
After an 80 20 random split the training set had 66,756 emails and the test set had 16,690 emails with class proportions preserved
Cross validation accuracies across five folds were 0.9733, 0.9766, 0.9762, 0.9759, and 0.9755 with mean approximately 0.9751, indicating stable performance
The selected model (from Fold 2) achieved 97.82 percent overall accuracy on the held out test set
Confusion matrix on 16,690 test emails: of 7,908 ham, 7,800 correctly classified and 108 misclassified as spam; of 8,782 spam, 8,526 correctly classified and 256 misclassified as ham
Per-class metrics: spam precision 0.97 recall 0.99 F1 0.98; ham precision 0.99 recall 0.97 F1 0.98; overall accuracy reported 0.98 with macro and weighted averages 0.98
High and consistent precision and recall for both classes demonstrate the model effectively distinguishes spam from ham on this combined dataset
Conclusion: Naive Bayes exhibits excellent performance and stability for spam detection on the evaluated dataset and is suitable as a foundation for practical filtering systems

Limitation and future work: potential improvements include hybridizing Naive Bayes with other algorithms and adding contextual or semantic analysis to better capture intent and overcome independence assumption weaknesses
